sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Hello and welcome to Euronews tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: I'm Angela Barnes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Here's our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Trying to put a name to the faces of the 27 people, including four children, who drowned in the English Channel on Wednesday night as police open a criminal investigation into the incident.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Stopping the blame game.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The UK and France vow to do more to prevent illegal crossings, as Emmanuel Macron says it's not just a French problem.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Time for a booster. The EU proposes a nine-month acceptance period for Covid vaccines as a new wave of infections sweeps across Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And Pfizer is authorised for children. The European Medicines Agency approves the jab for 5 to 11 year olds, offering millions more protection from COVID-19.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: French authorities have begun the task of identifying the 27 people, including four children who drowned trying to cross the English Channel on Wednesday night.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: There are at least one pregnant woman among the dead, who are believed to be mostly Kurds and Iraq or Iran.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: One Iraqi and one Somalian man who were rescued are being treated in hospital.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: A criminal investigation has been opened into the incident. Four men are suspected of having direct involvement. But attempted crossings from Calais is nothing new, French police say. The deaths were a dreaded but expected tragedy. This is a dramatic scenario.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: First of all, it was unfortunately something that could have been foreseen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: A scenario of horror that we'd feared and dreaded occurred yesterday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It is a very busy place of passage at the commercial level.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Boats continuing to pass between France and Great Britain, with a multitude of makeshift boats embarking to try their luck, and are confronted by these large boats and perhaps by the sea that is sometimes out of control.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well Gregoire, Laurie joins me now live from Calais. Gregoire, this is a huge number of people to have died trying to cross the Channel. Is the feeling in Calais that something like this was expected?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Indeed, it was expected. NGOs, associations working closely with the migrants expected that such a tragedy could happen. It is not new to see people trying to reach the United Kingdom through boats. There has been a change of strategy by smugglers in the recent month, and so they expected that such a tragedy would happen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: For them, it is something not unexpected, and actually they are quite angry towards authorities because they have raised the alarm a month ago saying that this would happen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And so for them it is of course sadness that is that we can feel here when we talk to NGOs or associations working with the migrants. Greg, record numbers of attempts to cross from France to the UK this year. What's behind the rise and what's being done to try and counter it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It is despair, first of all, that push migrants to try to reach the United Kingdom.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This is the same motto repeated by NGOs and associations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And I talked earlier with the mayor of Sangat, who told us that there are no more limits for the smugglers, and that's something that has changed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: He raised the alarm in August 2019, saying that they've first seen the first boats trying to reach the United Kingdom.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And some months ago, smugglers, human traffickers, were waiting for good weather to try to push migrants to reach the United Kingdom.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And now it is no more the case.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now whatever the weather is, the smugglers are pushing migrants on diggies, on boats, and that's one thing that has changed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So what France can do, the government said that they would provide more coast guards, more drones, more cameras, try to avoid migrants to try to get on boats but the answer will be also Europeans and ministers for migration French ministers, Belgian ministers, Dutch ministers, British ministers should gather with the European Commission on Sunday in Calais to try to find out a European solution to this tragedy. Gregor Laurie in Calais there. Thank you very much for that update.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The UK and France have both blamed each other for not doing enough to prevent not only this tragedy,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: but also the number of people trying to cross the channel. UK Home Secretary Priti Patel told the House of Commons that London had offered to put British officers on the northern coast of France to secure the area and stop vulnerable people risking their lives, but that the offer was rejected by Paris, she said.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, Patel also said there are no quick fixes to the long-standing challenge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: What happened yesterday was a dreadful shock.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It was not a surprise, but it is also a reminder of how vulnerable people are put at peril when in the hands of criminal gangs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: This is about addressing long-term pull factors, smashing the criminal gangs that treat human beings as cargo, and tackling supply chains. This requires a coordinated international effort. And I've been in constant contact with my counterparts from France, Poland, Austria, Belgium, Italy, and Greece, to name just a few. French President Emmanuel Macron has called for stronger cooperation among European countries, saying that it isn't just a French problem.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: We need to strengthen cooperation with Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany, but also the British and the Commission.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: This is the decision that has been taken to better prevent arrivals on French soil and to better integrate the British in the prevention of these flows by dismantling the networks of smugglers. We have dismantled several dozen of them in the last few weeks and I salute the mobilisation of our prefects in the region and our internal security forces, but we need a stronger European cooperation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, for more on this now, our reporter Victoria Smith is in London for us. Victoria, good to see you there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Now, the UK and France proposing to do more, but blaming each other on the number of people trying to cross the Channel.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So what are their plans for working together this time?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Very much up in the air, sadly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Obviously, everyone's horrified by what happened in the channel last night.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Boris Johnson has said he's shocked and appalled.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: He said that here at Westminster.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And he's urging France to do more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But for his part, President Macron says, stop making this a political issue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Of course, it is a political issue in so much as the UK has offered France, for example, some 54 billion euros to help stop the crossings taking place from French soil, from French beaches.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: There are reports that French police have stood by and watched the boats take off, cast away.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Also, of course, it's a political issue because there has been some success in preventing other kinds of crossings.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We used to see the migrants coming over on trucks and trains.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Now they're turning to boats because that's what the people smugglers are offering, and that's where the problem remains.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Just to give you a figure on that, Angela, some 26,000 migrants have managed to cross the Channel this year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Only five have been returned.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Victoria, it's a shocking figure, but Priti Patel and the government have been heavily criticised, haven't they, for the handling of the migrant crisis over the years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Would you say, or is it felt that this now is a turning point?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, let's see. The critics are saying that the UK needs to look at its policies again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It needs to look at the politics and find, perhaps, alternative, safe routes for those who are desperately needing to seek asylum.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Others of course point to Brexit. They say the reason for the standoff, if you like, between France and Britain is that Brexit has got in the way. Britain now has to negotiate individually with each European country. That didn't used to be the case. And there could be some difficulties. There are some difficulties because of of that you can see it in the figures far fewer people being returned this year than they were last year when Britain was still following EU rules and still of course the migrants come in record numbers they are setting off they're paying people traffickers people smugglers three thousand pounds each to get into an overcrowded inflatable boat and to take their chances on the world's busiest shipping route just as winter begins to strike victoria thank you very much for that update while staying on this now bruno bunnell an mp representing macron's on marsh movement joins us now to discuss it further thank you very much for joining us this evening on the show Thank you very much for joining us this evening on the show. Now, you've been talking about this today, I've seen, a lot.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And of course, the UK has offered to help police the French border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: What are your thoughts on that?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Do you think it's a good idea?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Because there are concerns, aren't there, in Paris, over national sovereignty?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: You know, anything that could help to resolve this issue in the short term is good to take, but it's just the peak of the iceberg. I think that behind this agreement for common or joint patrolling, there is a much bigger picture to consider. And, to be honest with you, it's it is very disappointing to see that people keep pointing fingers on both sides of the channel, saying, oh, the French are not doing their job, or the U.K. should change their labor law.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: I mean, we just have to understand that we're facing massive migrant waves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And this one is going to grow more and more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: It's a never-ending story. So we need to coordinate action to join forces against the gangs, against the smugglers at EU plus UK level, and not just make little details here and there, pretending it will solve the problem.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Bruno, let's talk about the smugglers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: What needs to be done to really stop these illegal crossings?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Because nothing really is working so far, has it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, what needs to be done is really to open a real war against them, meaning that dismantling the networks, because they capture the attention of those people on their lands, right, in Africa sometime or in other territories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And they build the dream of the UK from Iceland for them to find jobs and money.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And they take these people and they make them pay a very significant amount of money.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: So at the end of the day, I think that this is intelligence and forces against the gangs that we need to pursue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Okay, well, that was Bruno Bonnel.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: One more question for you as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The UK and France have agreed, haven't they, to step up their efforts, but they've also been criticising each other over their efforts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Could this be a turning point in the way Paris and London treat these people?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, I think it could be a turning point for many, many things. And if it could be a base for a much bigger trust in the future between the two territories, it would be really something that would be a good conclusion of this tragedy. Again, we need to join forces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We are allies. We are friends.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And we need to understand that nobody is to be blamed here, but everybody has to be on board for those people not to die anymore.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Bruno Bonnell, thank you very much for joining us and for your insight there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, stay with us on the program.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Still to come, a clampdown on political ads.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The European Commission outlines plans to make them more transparent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Germany has become the fifth European country

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: to officially pass 100,000 coronavirus-related deaths.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Public health officials say 351 people have died with the virus in the last 24 hours.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Hospitals have warned that few intensive care beds remain available.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: beds remain available. On Thursday, almost 4,000 were occupied by Covid-19 patients, forcing the transfer of some German patients abroad for treatment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The EU's drugs regulator has given the green light for Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine to be used in children aged 5 to 11. The European Medicines Agency estimates that the jab is over 90% effective in preventing symptoms in young children. Austria, currently under lockdown due to a spike in cases, has already started vaccinations among this age range.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The European Commission has updated its travel advice for member states, including fresh guidelines for the coronavirus pass, which is used for cross-border travel.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It recommends the certificate should be valid for nine months after the first full vaccination.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Research suggests vaccine protection wanes after six months and the EMA said an additional three months may be needed to ensure national jab campaigns can adjust and citizens are able to access booster shots.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, let's head to Brussels to speak to Shona Murray for more on this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Shona, good to see you there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So, what other proposals is the EU suggesting to try and counter the fourth wave gripping the bloc?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And are the 27 member states likely to come on board?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, this relates specifically just to travel within the European Union because there's a feeling that nobody wants to go back to the situation we were in last year where some member states were closing their borders or that there was only essential travel.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So this facilitates it in the way that it extends the COVID pass until at least the end of next summer. And also now people can get their booster shots added onto their COVID cert. The rule essentially is that, as you mentioned there, vaccines start to wane after six months. So it gives a person the next three months to get their booster shot. So essentially you get a booster shot within nine months of your second vaccine or your full vaccination.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And this means that you can travel onwards.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It'll essentially prevent people from travelling unless they've been fully vaccinated or have a negative PCR test.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Now, nothing really changes for the unvaccinated in terms of travel, other than they will likely have to quarantine in places and and also continue to have a pcr test because this really relates to travel and other restrictions around unvaccinated are for member states themselves this is an eu-wide um plan or proposal just to allow travel within the blockc. And Shona, vaccination itself, though, is still a huge issue for the EU, isn't it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Because Ursula von der Leyen is saying that just a quarter of adults are vaccinated, it's still not double jabbed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Could we see more restrictions being put on those that are unvaccinated?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Certainly within the member states.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: When it comes to these issues, the EU doesn't have competence, so it can't talk about how unvaccinated people are treated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The EU only deals with the single market and the right to freedom of travel.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But we have seen, and in Austria initially, the restrictions were placed on the unvaccinated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Now it's on everyone because the vaccination rates are so low there, 65%.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: unvaccinated now it's on everyone because the vaccination rates are so low there 65 germany they're mulling it over that it should be unvaccinated people should have very limited access to facilities and so and i think you know as ursula von der leyen was saying there is huge divergence within the eu around countries vaccination rates ireland malta denmark they have around 92 93 of the adult population vaccinated, yet still are under pressure when it comes to ICUs, even as a small percentage of those people are in hospitals and in ICUs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But countries like Bulgaria have less than 30%, around 28% of people vaccinated. So in those situations, it's very unlikely that you see a big uptake on booster jabs. And so obviously, this issue about unvaccinated versus vaccinated will continue apace given the next few months and given how contagious and infectious the delta variant is shona maria correspondent in brussels thank you very much now the european commission has unveiled plans to make political advertising more transparent

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: tech giants and other online platforms will be forced to clearly label paid political adverts or face hefty fines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: They'll also be barred from using personal data to target voters.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Sándor Dziuráos reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Brussels is clamping down on political ads.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The European Commission has presented plans to force online platforms like A különböző kérdés a politikai adatokat. A Európai Kommisszió előtt állított plánokat, hogy Facebook-os online platformokat jelentősítéssel, vagy a politikai adatokat, vagy a kétszerződéssel, meglepődjük.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Az online adatokat megváltoztatóan egy visszatérődési, hosszú metódokat, ahogy az EU-ben beszél.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Amikor ezt a lényegtől előadjuk, a műsorok meg tudják jelentősítéssel a politikai adatokat, mert a kétszerződéssel Once this law is adopted, the users will be able to clearly distinguish the ads from organic content, because paid content will be clearly labeled.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Citizens will be able to know why they are seeing an ad, who paid for it, what data were used to target them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Big tech would have to reveal what data was used and refrain from using sensitive data to target people with political ads.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Some criticise the initiative as a dangerous move which would create a European Ministry of Truth.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: This is not the case in the current plans, according to one expert.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: There is no concrete mechanism being proposed that would endanger the freedom of speech, that would be a very systematic, let's say, fact checker done by the authorities themselves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But I think what we will end up with is some sort of soft mechanism, soft co-regulation also, between the authorities and the platforms to ensure that the content is not misleading, is not manipulative and it is transparent as regards who posted there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The rules on political ads must be approved by MEPs and EU leaders and are likely to enter into force by 2024.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The plan is part of a larger clampdown in big tech to protect democracy and comes just weeks after fresh revelations of wrongdoings reported by Facebook whistleblower Francis Hogan.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Stay with us. After the break we'll be looking at Europe's first retirement home for elephants.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Now, France has opened Europe's first retirement home for elephants.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Elephant Haven is hoping to house wild animals from zoos and circuses following a ban on their use in shows in some European countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Rebecca Daunt reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: In the heart of Limousin, France, a sparsely populated agricultural region famous for its prime cattle, lies a haven for another gentle giant.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: On a plot of 29 hectares, these barns have been purposely built to house elephants through their golden years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And 52-year-old Gandhi is the centre's very first resident.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: It's the first and only sanctuary for elephants here in Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: One of the reasons for this is that sometimes there's a lot of old elephants in zoos that fight with each other, and it's always difficult to find a place for just one old elephant.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Also there are a lot of countries that have banned wild animals in circuses.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: But where are you going to put these animals?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: At least 20 European countries, including Greece, France and Austria, have banned the use of wild animals in circuses and live shows.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Costing a grand total of 1 million euros, this project was made possible thanks to generous donations made by NGOs such as the Brigitte Bardot Foundation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We leave you now with a no comment from Stockholm, where an architecture museum is keeping up tradition by holding its annual gingerbread competition.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Thanks for watching Euronews Tonight. Tack så mycket. Jag ska. Grazie a tutti.
